The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities is organized into 9 Sections.  Since this facility only has flammable chemicals and no toxic chemicals covered under 40 CFR 68, and because it is a Program 2 Propane Storage facility with no history of accidents, several of the sections do not apply.  The table below shows the equivalency between the organization of the guidance document and the Factor Gas RMP.

	correcting non-compliance found during regular audits of the facility.

Prevention Program

The South Wallingford Long Siding does not operate under the guidelines of the Occupational, Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program since the facility is normally unmanned and remote. The facility does, however, operate under the requirements of Program Level 2 in the RMP regulations. Analysis of the potential hazards of the process, training of employees, and emphasis on safety helps to avoid serious accidental releases. 

Five Year Accident History

No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death, property damage, or offsite impacts from a propane release has occurred at the South Wallingford Long Siding within the last five years.
Emergency Response Program
Factor Gas has never had an accident involving propane that caused or might have caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelters-in-place.  In the event of an emergency involving the propane facilities described herein, it is Factor Gass policy to notify the local fire department and VR officials to coordinate an emergency response.  For major emergency response, Factor Gas and Vermont Railway have agreements with private emergency response contractors to provide these resources when and where needed on a 24-hour basis.  

The worst-case release scenario is the rupture of a 30,000-gallon railcar resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite 0.4 miles, and there are approximately 103 people in residences within this distance. The alternative release scenario is a release from the railcar relief valve for 5 minutes or 2520 lbs./min and a vapor cloud explosion. Introduction and Policies

Factor Gas Liquids Inc (Factor Gas) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment, the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. Factor Gas managements philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the environmental, health, and safety management systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and through open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the facility. This will meet the requirements of EPAs Risk Management Program in 40 CFR 68.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

The South Wallingford Long Siding in Rockingham, VT, is operated by Factor Gas Company. At the facility, railcars are stored on the property until procurement can find a suitable market for the liquids. Odorized propane is the only substance regulated under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) that is present at the South Wallingford Long Siding in amounts above the threshold quantity. The facility is classified as Program Level 2 under the regulation because it is a remote, unmanned facility used for storage of railcars only.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by Factor Gas. These high standards include:
	operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations; 
	operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized; 
	operating and maintaining asset
